cot.content:

question:
who played john coffey in the movie the green mile

Answer:

To answer the question, I need to recall the cast of the movie "The Green Mile," which is based on a novel by Stephen King. John Coffey is one of the main characters in the story, and I need to identify the actor who portrayed him in the film adaptation. The movie was released in 1999 and features a notable cast. Answer: Michael Clarke Duncan played John Coffey in the movie "The Green Mile."

anchoring.content:
You are a cognitive scientist, to answer the following question:
who played john coffey in the movie the green mile
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['BULLET::::- John Coffey in "The Green Mile" (1996) novel and its 1999 film adaptation (played by Michael Clarke Duncan)\n', 'BULLET::::- 1999: Michael Clarke Duncan – "The Green Mile" as John Coffey\n', 'BULLET::::- John Coffey (Michael Clarke Duncan) in "The Green Mile" (1999)\n', 'BULLET::::- John Coffey, a character in the Stephen King novel "The Green Mile" and the subsequent film\n', 'BULLET::::- John Coffey from "The Green Mile".\n', 'BULLET::::- In Stephen King\'s novel "The Green Mile", the protagonist John Coffey, a giant African-American with healing ability, is given a Saint Christopher medal after healing a woman. This scene was included within the 1999 film adaptation of the book.\n', 'BULLET::::- In Stephen King\'s serial novel "The Green Mile" (1996), John Coffey (played by Michael Clarke Duncan in the 1999 film) is similar to Lennie in that he is large, unintelligent, and innocent at heart. In both stories, mice fall into their care at some point and ultimately, at the time of their deaths, both Lennie and John Coffey were executed in the most compassionate way possible under the circumstances that occur in both novels. Percy Wetmore, one of the guards along the Green Mile and Curley share roles as an antagonist; Percy (who is notably a described as a small man, much like Curley), is seen constantly antagonizing John Coffey much like Curley\'s fight with Lennie.\n', 'Michael Clarke Duncan (December 10, 1957September 3, 2012) was an American actor best known for his breakout role as John Coffey in "The Green Mile" (1999), for which he was nominated for the Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor and various similar honors. He also appeared in motion pictures such as "Armageddon" (1998), "The Whole Nine Yards" (2000), "The Scorpion King" (2002), "Daredevil" (2003), and "" (2006). He also had voice roles in films such as "Brother Bear" (2003), "Kung Fu Panda" (2008) and "Green Lantern" (2011).\n', "The Green Mile is a 1996 serial novel by American writer Stephen King. It tells the story of death row supervisor Paul Edgecombe's encounter with John Coffey, an unusual inmate who displays inexplicable healing and empathetic abilities. The serial novel was originally released in six volumes before being republished as a single-volume work. The book is an example of magical realism.\n", 'A first-person narrative told by Paul Edgecombe, the novel switches between Paul as an old man in the Georgia Pines nursing home writing down his story in 1996, and his time in 1932 as the block supervisor of the Cold Mountain Penitentiary death row, nicknamed "The Green Mile" for the color of the floor\'s linoleum. This year marks the arrival of John Coffey, a tall powerfully built black man who has been convicted of raping and murdering two small white girls. During his time on the Mile, John interacts with fellow prisoners Eduard "Del" Delacroix, a Cajun arsonist, rapist, and murderer, and William Wharton ("Billy the Kid" to himself, "Wild Bill" to the guards), a wild-acting and dangerous multiple murderer who is determined to make as much trouble as he can before he is executed. Other inhabitants include Arlen Bitterbuck, a Native American convicted of killing a man in a fight over a pair of boots (also the first character to die in the electric chair); Arthur Flanders, a real estate executive who killed his father to perpetrate insurance fraud, and whose sentence is eventually commuted to life imprisonment (while serving his sentence, he is killed by another inmate in the laundry room); and Mr. Jingles, a mouse, to whom Del teaches various tricks.\n']

This scene was included within the 1999 film adaptation of the book.\n', 'BULLET::::- In Stephen King\'s serial novel "The Green Mile" (1996), John Coffey (played by Michael Clarke Duncan in the 1999 film) is similar to Lennie in that he is large, unintelligent, and innocent at heart. In both stories, mice fall into their care at some point and ultimately, at the time of their deaths, both Lennie and John Coffey were executed in the most compassionate way possible under the circumstances that occur in both novels. Percy Wetmore, one of the guards along the Green Mile and Curley share roles as an antagonist; Percy (who is notably a described as a small man, much like Curley), is seen constantly antagonizing John Coffey much like Curley\'s fight with Lennie.\n', 'Michael Clarke Duncan (December 10, 1957September 3, 2012) was an American actor best known for his breakout role as John Coffey in "The Green Mile" (1999), for which he was nominated for the Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor and various similar honors. He also appeared in motion pictures such as "Armageddon" (1998), "The Whole Nine Yards" (2000), "The Scorpion King" (2002), "Daredevil" (2003), and "" (2006). He also had voice roles in films such as "Brother Bear" (2003), "Kung Fu Panda" (2008) and "Green Lantern" (2011).\n', "The Green Mile is a 1996 serial novel by American writer Stephen King. It tells the story of death row supervisor Paul Edgecombe's encounter with John Coffey, an unusual inmate who displays inexplicable healing and empathetic abilities. This year marks the arrival of John Coffey, a tall powerfully built black man who has been convicted of raping and murdering two small white girls. During his time on the Mile, John interacts with fellow prisoners Eduard "Del" Delacroix, a Cajun arsonist, rapist, and murderer, and William Wharton ("Billy the Kid" to himself, "Wild Bill" to the guards), a wild-acting and dangerous multiple murderer who is determined to make as much trouble as he can before he is executed. Other inhabitants include Arlen Bitterbuck, a Native American convicted of killing a man in a fight over a pair of boots (also the first character to die in the electric chair); Arthur Flanders, a real estate executive who killed his father to perpetrate insurance fraud, and whose sentence is eventually commuted to life imprisonment (while serving his sentence, he is killed by another inmate in the laundry room); and Mr. Jingles, a mouse, to whom Del teaches various tricks.\n']

To answer the question about who played John Coffey in the movie "The Green Mile," I will first recall the relevant details about the film and its characters. "The Green Mile" is a film adaptation of Stephen King's novel, released in 1999. John Coffey is a central character in the story, and I need to identify the actor who portrayed him.

From the retrieved passages, I gather the following key points:

1. **Actor Identification**: The passages consistently confirm that Michael Clarke Duncan played the role of John Coffey in the film adaptation. This is crucial information that accurately attributes the role to the correct actor.

2. **Character Traits**: John Coffey is described as a "giant African-American with healing ability." This description not only highlights his physical presence but also emphasizes his supernatural traits, which are integral to the character's role in the narrative.

3. **Awards and Recognition**: It is noted that Michael Clarke Duncan received an Academy Award nomination for Best Supporting Actor for his portrayal of John Coffey. This detail underscores the significance of his performance and its recognition within the film industry.

4. **Narrative Context**: The passages explain that John Coffey is an inmate on death row who possesses "inexplicable healing and empathetic abilities." Understanding this context is essential for grasping the character's impact on the story and his relationships with other characters.

This comparison enriches the understanding of character archetypes and their roles in literature.

By synthesizing this information, I can enhance the reasoning process to ensure a comprehensive understanding of the character and the actor's significance in the film.

Michael Clarke Duncan played John Coffey in the movie "The Green Mile." He is portrayed as a giant African-American man with healing abilities, and his performance earned him an Academy Award nomination for Best Supporting Actor.

question_info.question: who played john coffey in the movie the green mile
passages:
BULLET::::- John Coffey in "The Green Mile" (1996) novel and its 1999 film adaptation (played by Michael Clarke Duncan)
BULLET::::- 1999: Michael Clarke Duncan – "The Green Mile" as John Coffey
BULLET::::- John Coffey (Michael Clarke Duncan) in "The Green Mile" (1999)
BULLET::::- John Coffey, a character in the Stephen King novel "The Green Mile" and the subsequent film
BULLET::::- John Coffey from "The Green Mile".
BULLET::::- In Stephen King's novel "The Green Mile", the protagonist John Coffey, a giant African-American with healing ability, is given a Saint Christopher medal after healing a woman. This scene was included within the 1999 film adaptation of the book.
BULLET::::- In Stephen King's serial novel "The Green Mile" (1996), John Coffey (played by Michael Clarke Duncan in the 1999 film) is similar to Lennie in that he is large, unintelligent, and innocent at heart. In both stories, mice fall into their care at some point and ultimately, at the time of their deaths, both Lennie and John Coffey were executed in the most compassionate way possible under the circumstances that occur in both novels. Percy Wetmore, one of the guards along the Green Mile and Curley share roles as an antagonist; Percy (who is notably a described as a small man, much like Curley), is seen constantly antagonizing John Coffey much like Curley's fight with Lennie.
Michael Clarke Duncan (December 10, 1957September 3, 2012) was an American actor best known for his breakout role as John Coffey in "The Green Mile" (1999), for which he was nominated for the Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor and various similar honors. He also appeared in motion pictures such as "Armageddon" (1998), "The Whole Nine Yards" (2000), "The Scorpion King" (2002), "Daredevil" (2003), and "" (2006). He also had voice roles in films such as "Brother Bear" (2003), "Kung Fu Panda" (2008) and "Green Lantern" (2011).
The Green Mile is a 1996 serial novel by American writer Stephen King. It tells the story of death row supervisor Paul Edgecombe's encounter with John Coffey, an unusual inmate who displays inexplicable healing and empathetic abilities. The serial novel was originally released in six volumes before being republished as a single-volume work. The book is an example of magical realism.
A first-person narrative told by Paul Edgecombe, the novel switches between Paul as an old man in the Georgia Pines nursing home writing down his story in 1996, and his time in 1932 as the block supervisor of the Cold Mountain Penitentiary death row, nicknamed "The Green Mile" for the color of the floor's linoleum. This year marks the arrival of John Coffey, a tall powerfully built black man who has been convicted of raping and murdering two small white girls. During his time on the Mile, John interacts with fellow prisoners Eduard "Del" Delacroix, a Cajun arsonist, rapist, and murderer, and William Wharton ("Billy the Kid" to himself, "Wild Bill" to the guards), a wild-acting and dangerous multiple murderer who is determined to make as much trouble as he can before he is executed. Other inhabitants include Arlen Bitterbuck, a Native American convicted of killing a man in a fight over a pair of boots (also the first character to die in the electric chair); Arthur Flanders, a real estate executive who killed his father to perpetrate insurance fraud, and whose sentence is eventually commuted to life imprisonment (while serving his sentence, he is killed by another inmate in the laundry room); and Mr. Jingles, a mouse, to whom Del teaches various tricks.
